sen.e: Some books mention about Mitsuyuki Toki, the son of Mitsuhira, who sided with the Imperial court (the retired Emperor Gotoba) and served as Toki hogandai (an adiministrative official of the retired Emperor's office) in Jokyu War in 1221, when Mino province became a main battle field.

sen.j: かつての「康行の乱」では土岐氏庶流の多くが康行に付随したため、新たに美濃守護となった頼忠の土岐西池田氏は外様の国人である富島氏と斎藤氏を守護代として重用する。
sen.e: In "Yasuyuki TOKI's rebellion", which occurred in the past, many branch families of the Toki clan sided with Yukiyasu, therefore, the Toki-Nishiikeda clan headed by Yoritada, who newly became Mino no Shugo, appointed the Tomishima clan and the Saito clan, which were local lord of Tozama (military clans who are not a member of the Shogun's family) as shugodai (deputy of Shugo).

sen.e: Later, at the time when Mochimasu TOKI served as Shugo, a conflict between the Tomishima clan and the Saito clan was escalated into a civil war, involving the whole Mino Province (Mino Civil War).

sen.j: 最終的に勝利した斎藤氏が、守護代を単独で継承して美濃の実権を握るようになった一方、持益は隠居させられ、斎藤利永が擁立する庶流の土岐成頼が守護になった。
sen.e: Finally winning the war, the Saito clan unilaterally took over the position of Shugodai and gained real power in Mino Province, whereas Mochimasu was forced to retire, then Shigeyori Toki, who was a member of a branch famiy of theToki clan, and backed up by Toshimaga Saito, became Shugo.

sen.e: Myochin SAITO's case is famous as a good example of Gekokujo (an inverted social order when the lowly reigned over the elite) in this period along with the case of Takakage ASAKURA (the 7th head of the Asakura family) in Echizen Province, under which the power of Shugodai (deputy provincial constable) exceeded that of Shugo (provincial constable).

sen.j: 文明 (日本)12年（1480年）に妙椿が死去すると、斎藤利国（妙純）と斎藤利藤が争い（文明美濃の乱）、その後は妙純と守護代の家宰石丸利光が戦った（船田合戦）。
sen.e: After the death of Myochin in 1480, Toshikuni SAITO (Myojun) and Toshifuji SAITO fought against each other (Bunmei Mino War), then, Myojun and Toshimitsu ISHIMARU, who was Shugodai and a main retainer of the Saito clan), had a fihght against each other (the Battle of Funada).
